title: Multisector VEN
segmentation: Good afternoon, I think we've passed past midday.
I'm going to be very quick 10 minutes then would like to say is I'm not going to push this on a technology front.
Or a process from?

I would like to take this in the direction of a people front or people context, so I'm going to say today is our experience based with one to one experiences shared with people who are transacting collaborative agreements and people are involved in both the good side and sometimes the downside of collaboration.
Just a little bit back my company.
Basically we we've been talking this morning about how to do this and take this forward.
One of the first things that was realized by Yorkshire forward Drda was we actually needed a special purpose vehicle to make this happen.
A business that is not focused on collaboration in a new paradigm, but is only focused on it 20% or 10% of the time it won't happen.
So we created a company whose sole purpose is to bring them into being and to make it sustainable.
Our business model is actually located on the premise that we're successful from our success.
We can keep the business going.
So some respect to make this work.
We've basically had put houses on the program.
So for us there is a clear commercial sense.
From day one about how this operates.
We do particularly focus on small medium enterprises.
I think the discussions around large companies being involved in small company collaboration is an interesting one.
But in essence, 99.9% of businesses in the European Union are SMS.
So there is a big market is a big demand.
Our culture is basically we will not do a deal and less is win win for both sides.
We do not use the van to help large procurers aggregate large contracts for purely commercial gain.
We do not do it.
We do actually and are more successful in Lincoln.
Our activities to international markets.
Our biggest.
Input of opportunities.
It currently is coming from United States.
So really when we look for opportunities, our own region sometimes is limited.
We have a very much an international brokerage network and the interesting thing I was observing today is nobody mentioned the word broker.
And how important a broker is in a network, either brokering information or brokering opportunities, or brokering relationships.
I cannot stress from our experience how important having a professional community of brokers us.
And Lastly, I think everybody is aware of the international markets and international challenges.
I think.
I think it must be said about that.
So what do we do?
We use the word van, and in some respects we've been very.
Mindful of not complicated what is an overload of initiatives in the United Kingdom about collaboration?
There is product lifecycle management PLM.
There are lots and lots of initiatives in UK, particularly in this arena.
The other thing is, well, is.
We felt it was necessary to be very clear to SMS in terms of what they get.
To be part of this membership.
So rather than putting me through a process, we're actually given me some value add.
Some USPS that he can market.
So where we help businesses actually prequalifying a business?
For new potential markets, we're helping them with their marketing strategy.
Well, effectively acting as a gateway to other sectors.
We use common ITII have a little bit of a bugbear myself, personally about interoperability.
Most of our SMS don't have these systems.
They're lucky to have email.
So in essence, we provided them single system on a single platform which is eliminated.
A lot of the need for lots and lots of interoperability.
We think it's very an important point.
From our lessons, we need to configure to the exact needs of both the user.
Customer.
One of the big lessons we've learned is you need a professional community of buyers as well as sellers.
If your offer is not tuned exactly to the customer, he won't understand what you're saying.
He won't get the point.
In that case we had experts where read very good offers.
But the buyer did not understand the message.
So big Leszno is is to work on the by community as well as the people are selling.
I think the big important point at the bottom is it has to be seen to be transparent, open and equitable.
Everybody needs to be seen to be given a chance, whether they've got a chance of winning it or not.
Predetermination of networks can potentially destroy the trust in your network and destroy your network, ultimately.
Another important point is to tell people what you won't do in collaboration and the things that we always say we are not a guarantor.
We were not underwrite your contracts.
So where things do go wrong?
Please don't come back to me asking me for £1,000,000 or 10,000,000 pounds.
Another thing we think is very important point is we're not a competent developer.
For a collaboration network, we think that's a conflict of interest.
It would be a bit like writing a diagnostic and saying I think you're weak in these areas, but I have a package of training that you can pay for here which will deliver it.
So we don't see that as being for us an adequate solution.
What we see is the universities, the manufacturing advisory services have been a key linchpin into Filipinos competence.
So what are we doing?
Generally, we've been working a number of sectors.
I think I'll give you a heads up on few sectors in the advanced engineering.
Metals were focused in things on UAV sensor packs.
We're now talking about transitioning businesses from metals to composite aircraft.
In healthcare.
I'm going to do a particular example in healthcare where we're working on social enterprises out of our surgery.
In chemicals we've just launched a network to create networks which will be compliant for reach ready.
Another EU legislation, which is going to put massive demands on the chemical industry and the SMB is going to be badly affected.
So in that area we're looking at reach.
We're also looking at networks of personal care.
We see personal care being a massive opportunity for Living Labs, so we're going to be taking that forward in new year.
If food and drink will be working in functional foods and also locally delivered food to schools and hospitals.
In digital we just signed a network up to E learning contracts with the University for Industry, which is going to focus on serious games and learning.
For disadvantaged kids.
But the big point, I think for this is Vin recognizes.
This is about adoption.
If there's no international acceptance or collaboration about adoption will be an isolated island of expertise.
Also, there needs to be this adoption principle.
No question which came first.
The chicken or the egg?
In the case of an was it, was it the community development became first or the opportunity generation.
In essence, they both come at the same time or similar.
And this is about roles about who does what.
The Rdas and industrial groups have very important parts to play in acting as a broker.
In acting in developing levels of competency, both innovation and competitiveness.
You can't have an opportunity for filled with data network and you can't have a network waiting for an opportunity.
So the two need to be brought together.
Businesses have a big challenge in front of them in terms of having a trusted community.
Another point, think?
I don't think we've highlighted enough today in the discussions with this word trust.
In open business forums, people must trust each other and have a basis of trust.
If I don't trust somebody, I don't work with him, or if I don't trust them enough, I'll create a closed door environment in which to work.
I non disclosure non compete so one of the big measures or indicators of van.
In the future, is the degree of trust.
And the ability for people to partner with people.
I think that's going to be key indicator.
And where do opportunities come from?
We can effectively have an avalanche of opportunities.
Members bring his opportunities.
We have commercial brokers working around the planet bringing opportunities.
Pick yours, brings opportunities, and some of them we do ourselves.
We instigate opportunities, there are lots and lots of opportunities and in some respects Ven does it consider itself an innovator.
What then considers itself to be is two things.
Future orientated and adaptive.
We do not count patents.
We do not count intellectual property rights.
What we count our relationships.
And our ability to form a relationship very quickly.
So give an example of one that we're working on in a social context.

In our region with people on the ground and I'm going to take a slightly a bit outside what's being discussed this morning and I'm going to talk about systems and the system relationships with collaboration.
And the errors like to focus on is the relationship between health and wealth.
Or in this case, the relationship between Regional Health and cluster wealth.
Because there is a connection in our region between these two items.
So here we have an economic driver for the need for collaboration to deliver benefits to the region.
According to vehicle currently delivers it is a curious called the National Health Service.
The only chest in the UK.
Expense is the second biggest spend in the UK in terms of taxation just behind education.
The thing that's changing and changing in the market now in the National Health Services.
In days gone by, they would have measured themselves on treatment.
How fast can I treat somebody?
And I think this is a great example between being lean and being agile.
DHS became very good at treating people very quickly, but the problem we faced was that queue at the door was getting longer.
So no matter how well we improved, our process is.
We could not overcome the massive hurdle of public health.
So something's got to change.
And this change came about by looking at it from a sustainable point of view.
I'm looking at the connections between the social, economic and commercial base in the region.
So a bit lately diagram that Roberto puts up.
We looked all three aspects, so we looked at this thing called a total health care system.
And the system that drives.
The need for collaboration is poverty.
In the 21st century in the UK.
The divide between the rich and poor is getting greater and greater and greater.
There are some numbers done.
And effectively in I think 1214.
In England, there's a great event called the signing of the Magna Carta.
Where Ken Jeong gave rights to the people and signed away his rights.
But the rights were buried in only 26 barons in the country.
Almost 600 years later, plus the same percentage of rights and wealth is the same.
We have not created wealth beyond the same percentage that existed when King John signed Magna Carta.
And that's a very key element.
So what happens?
Currently is we have low pay unemployment and inadequate benefits.
So one of the questions for the future, how do we stimulate social networking?
How do we stimulate networking in effectively deprived areas deprived wards?
That has driven poverty and we measure poverty in a number of ways.
Poverty, Lisa three very fundamental health effects.
At least the health effects in terms of low birth weight.
Physicality.
Psychological health effects.
And also behavior.
Tries behavior.

Those three things drive for health care system and no matter what else we do in their chairs, if we don't tackle these three things will never have enough money to treat the people that come through the door.
And another factor that I'd like to draw attention to the outcome of all this is if we look at the region of Yorkshire and Humber.
Each one of these areas is what we call an award.
Health Ward is a bit like having election Ward.
The difference in wealth in your post code in your region is 10 years.
So somebody who lives in a red area will live on average 10 years less with somebody living in a blue area.
So maybe the other thing we have to look at is what are the outputs we're looking for from successful collaboration?
It's not just IP's.
Wealth and wealth can be quality of life.
And also your life expectancy.
So there has to be a broader approach to collaboration, its impact on the regions.
So we've set up effectively three level.
Network.
The first level is effectively community businesses bidding to deliver locally large scale contracts on behalf of the NHS.
Within that community, we're setting up a professional community of lead developers and lead deliveries were effectively act as as coaches for the community.
We're also going to be rolling out a living lab for the end user patient.
So we can capture patient experience and relate that back to the professional community.
This is all been done currently through one opportunity Alogical opportunity in our region.
The other thing we focused on is effectively also looking at the buyer.
The person who makes the decisions to buy your services and looking educational support for them, and in this context we've created a professional buyer group to recognize a professional community.
So rather than tackle each business on its own individually, we're looking at group to group connection.
I'm even on, I think some lessons learned.
I think regional agencies and businesses cannot cannot act alone.
There has to be a current agreement and strategy in place.
I think there's definitely gotta be linkages between regional strategies and your business competence development.
I've seen many cases we have technology parks that are not linked to learning his skills agenda, so we have great technology but no skills transfer.
I think the other point we found is SMS need significant support to adapt.
A lot of support, probably 3 times the amount of money you're going to spend on your technology.
The Ardies need to support each other to create a collective network.
Otherwise islands of isolation occur.
And finally I think the key point is.
There is this idea of transformation.
I think there's also this need for transition.
We need to invest on transition strategies to help businesses adapt, not just go for The Big Bang and go for transformation strategies.
It could be a.
It could be a thing that could fail very big if not.
So the final statement is we need the ability to adapt.
And also I think we need to recognize that every business in every venture has a life cycle.
And will come to an end ultimately.
And finally request just fish off.
We have been working on this for a number of years.
We've been working with marker on a number of inches.
We're now making sort of an informal inquiry is to people are interested in finding out what we've done, how we've done it.
We're looking for sort of informal partners.
No, we're not talking about creating the community in terms of strict forms and rules.
This is more of a social network.
So that is interesting.
Please have a chat.
Thank you.
